Technological advancements and ever-changing work policies provide people with an option to work from home, rather than the office where they meet the team face to face. List out and discuss the advantages and disadvantages of working from home?
working from home is a dream for many but it has pitfalls. as many and more professionals are seeking a better work life balance and more companies adopt flexible polices to accomadate shifting workplace priorities and realities  the working from home option is becoming increasingly viable. By working at home we save on many hidden costs that usually occurs when working outside for a company. These include var wear and tear, fuel, road taxes, parking as weel as indirect costs. working from home is a good option for people who are not allowed to do job. They can gain knowledge by working at home and can also earn money. we can work on our own flexible times to some extent is the most important aspect of working from home. we can also work according to our environment, lighting, temparature, setting , mood basically working in a framework that suits as best and making us happy. working from home provides less distractions. unnecessary interruptions, unimportant meetings can all be avoided and work can be done more efficiently without any mistakes and making us happy. we can give time to our family members at the same time.a married women can work properly without any stress of coming back home on time and cooking. girls have a great advantage if they work from home because at present the girls are not safe .  removed from the stresses and distractions of the work place and working independent in their own preferred environment at their own place professionals are much happier and lot more productive. working from home also provides better health because when people work outside they are habituated of eating outside and thereby spoiling their health. they also maintain a better  work life balance. but their are some disadvantages 

     many people working at home  complain of isolation and lonliness as they cannot talk to their boss and cowokers  can make a person depress. although office distractions are avoided by working at home, different distractions may arise like interruptions from children, neighbours, family friends etc because of this we may make mistakes in our work. since there is no one looking over your work hours we may feel tempted to work endlessly. peoplle may become lazy to complete their work as they are working from home.work cannot be completed on time.  if  we have any doubts regarding anything we cannot take suggestions. there is no person to help us in giving solutions and through this we may end up by making mistakes in our work. the danger of being  overlooked for promotions and carrrer development  oppurtunities is quite real when we are away from office and other more visible employees are actively waiting for the promotions. we may not be aware of all these. working from home allowes us to work in team , make new friends and enjoy the corporate life outside. woking from home is not for anyone . it takes a lot of dedication and self -control and the discipline to motivate yourself to preserve in working at home alone over the long run without having any distractions  and losing drive and momentum. often a partial agreement where we report into the office once or twice a weekis the optimal arrangement as it allowes close interactions with colleagues and supervisors and ensures us to remain in touch with company developments while still permitting us the comfort and convinence of working from home.

June 2013 – Global Auto Industry Outlook

The auto industry is highly concentrated. The top 10 global automakers account for roughly 80% of the worldwide production and nearly 90% of total vehicles sold in the U.S.

In the first five months of 2013, General Motors Company ( GM ) led with a 18.0% market share in the U.S., followed by Ford Motor Co. ( F ) with a 16.4% market share, Toyota Motors Corp. ( TM ) with a 14.2% market share, Chrysler-Fiat with a 11.7% market share, and Honda Motor Co. ( HMC ) and Nissan Motor Co. ( NSANY ) at the last spots with 9.5% and 8.1% market shares, respectively.

Toyota recaptured the sales crown from General Motors by selling 9.75 million vehicles globally in 2012, which exceeded GM`s sales of 9.29 million vehicles. Germany`s Volkswagen AG ( VLKAY ) came third with sales of 9.07 million vehicles for the year.

OPPORTUNITIES

To remain competitive, the automakers will need to design vehicles that will cater to consumers in both mature and emerging markets while manufacturing them at low-cost using the most advanced technology.

For example, Ford has undertaken "One Manufacturing" strategy, which aims at producing multiple models from plants across the world in order to save production costs and fast adaptation to changes in consumer tastes. The automaker anticipates producing 4.5 models at each of its plants by 2015, up from 3.6 models currently.

Further, the automakers are concentrating on offering more optional features (which will save money on gas), even on the small and less gas-guzzler vehicles in order to attract buyers. The sale of optional features is helping them offset lower profit margins for small cars relative to large trucks.

The automakers continue to shift their production facilities from high-cost regions such as North America and the European Union to lower-cost regions such as China, India and South America. According to a study by CSM Worldwide, China and South America together will represent more than 50% of growth in global light vehicle production in the auto industry from 2008 to 2015.

The role of governments is highly significant. Their energy and environmental policies will be strongly responsible in molding the auto industry in the coming years. In late 2011, 13 major automakers, including Ford, GM, Chrysler, BMW, Honda, Hyundai, Jaguar/Land Rover, Kia, Mazda, Mitsubishi, Nissan, Toyota and Volvo, have signed letters of commitment with the U.S. Government to upgrade the fuel economy standard of cars and light-duty trucks to 54.5 miles per gallon (mpg) by 2025.
